paper_title.ja: 単相金属・合金の高温クリープ挙動：その理解と問題点（その１、その２）(解説)

paper_title.en: Power-law creep behavior of single-phase metallic materials(Review),Part 1 and 2(in Japanese)
Creep behavior and deformation substructures of Mg-Y alloys containing precipitates

description.en:
Compressive creep properties of Mg-Y alloys containing various amount of yttrium, having various initial microstructures were investigated at 530K. The effect of initial microstructures on the minimum creep rate is very slight, but the effect of yttrium content is significantly. On the other hand, the primary stage of creep is affected by the initial microstructure. Low creep rate was observed at the beginning of the creep by introducing fine precipitates within grain interiors.
TEM observations have been revealed that fine precipitates are formed in the supersaturated solid-solution during creep and this precipitation process is rapidly because the diffusivity of yttrium in magnesium is high and the precipitates are nucleated on dislocation lines. The fine precipitates tire effective to improve the primary creep behavior, but the initial microstructure does not affect on the minimum creep rate. The reason of the slight effect of the initial beta' microstructure on the minimum creep rate is considered to be the low stability of the pseudo-equilibrium phase beta' at high temperature. Dislocations are the most important nucleation sites for the fine beta' precipitates, so that the coupling of straining (pre-creep) and aging can enhance the precipitation and decrease significantly the strain-rate in the primary stage of creep.

paper_title.en: Effect of stressing direction in compression and tensile creep behavior of magnesium-aluminum solid solution alloys at around 600K

description.en: Creep characteristics of magnesium-aluminum solution strengthened alloys in both tensile and compression creep are investigate around 0.6T(m) (T-m: the melting temperature). Creep behavior depends both on the applied stress and on stressing direction. Minimum creep rates as characteristic value are always lower under tensile conditions than that under compression conditions, and vary up to ten times between tensile and compression at the same stress. Differences in minimum creep rates depend on the applied stress and are prominent in lower stresses. Cavitations occur under tensile condition, while dynamic recrystallization proceeds in compression near grain boundaries. Logarithmic of creep rates are proportional to creep strain in tertiary stage in compression. Acceleration in creep rate during tertiary creep in compression is mainly attributed to increase in mobile dislocation densities.

publication_name.en: PRICM 4: FORTH PACIFIC RIM INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON ADVANCED MATERIALS AND PROCESSING, VOLS I AND II

paper_title.en: Effects of initial microstructure on creep behavior of precipitation-hardened Mg-Y alloys at 530K

description.en:
Effect of the distribution of precipitates on compressive creep of Mg-Y alloys was investigated at 530K. Fine precipitates of meta-stable phase distributed homogeneously were obtained during static aging. On the other hand, pre-straining before aging enhanced precipitation. Pre-straining (pre-creep) also changes the distribution of precipitates; precipitates are introduced along dislocation lines. The effect of initial distribution of precipitates on the minimum creep rate is very slight, but the effect of yttrium content is dominant. On the other hand, the feature of primary creep is affected by the initial distribution of the precipitates. Low creep rate was observed at the beginning of creep when dislocations are pinned by the precipitates efficiently.
TEM observations have revealed that fine meta-stable precipitates beta' are formed from the supersaturated solid-solution during creep and this precipitation process is fast. The microstructural change is significant during creep and the deformation microstructures at the minimum creep rate are independent of initial distribution of precipitates. The fine beta' phase is effective to improve only the primary creep behavior, but the initial distribution of the beta' precipitates does not affect the minimum creep rate due to the inferior thermal stability of beta' phase. Dislocations act as the most important nucleation sites for the fine beta' precipitates, so that the coupling of straining (pre-creep) and aging can enhance the precipitation and decrease significantly the strain-rate in the primary stage of creep.

publication_name.en: PRICM 4: FORTH PACIFIC RIM INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON ADVANCED MATERIALS AND PROCESSING, VOLS I AND II

paper_title.en: Comparison of creep strength and models of solution-strengthened alloys in aluminum-magnesium binary system at around 0.6Tm

description.en: Creep strength of solution-hardened alloys in aluminum-magnesiurn system are compared and change of its creep characteristics are discussed based on viscous glide concepts. Normalized creep rates in the system are summarized and advantages of magnesium-based alloys as light heat resistant materials are pronounced. Change of creep behavior attributed to the breakaway of dislocation from solute atmosphere is discussed based on experimental results and numerical calculations. Huge differences in the normalized creep rates are attributed to mean internal stresses, and importance of quantitative evaluation of effective and internal stress is shown. Importance of considerations of creep mechanism and of its change are also pronounced.
